**Kubernetes version** (use `kubectl version`):

```
Client Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"6", GitVersion:"v1.6.0", GitCommit:"fff5156092b56e6bd60fff75aad4dc9de6b6ef37", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2017-03-28T16:36:33Z", GoVersion:"go1.7.5", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"darwin/amd64"}
Server Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"6", GitVersion:"v1.6.0", GitCommit:"fff5156092b56e6bd60fff75aad4dc9de6b6ef37", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2017-03-28T16:24:30Z", GoVersion:"go1.7.5", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}
```

**Environment**:
- **Cloud provider or hardware configuration**: baremetal
- **OS** (e.g. from /etc/os-release): centos7/ol7
- **Kernel** (e.g. `uname -a`): depends on box
- **Install tools**: custom
- **Others**:


**What happened**:

I have a pod with the following anti-affinity rule
```
      affinity:
        podAntiAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
          - labelSelector:
              matchExpressions:
              - key: k8s-app
                operator: In
                values:
                - kube-controller-manager
            topologyKey: kubernetes.io/hostname
```

I have 3 nodes where this pod can deploy to and run 3 replicas. So 1 pod per node. 

When i first applied the change to the manifest the current state of the cluster was:
```
kb get po -l k8s-app=kube-controller-manager -o wide
NAME                                       READY     STATUS        RESTARTS   AGE       IP         
kube-controller-manager-1756656909-36srf   1/1       Running       0          12d       10.5.57.4   
kube-controller-manager-1756656909-rrkvj   0/1       Terminating   0          12d       <none>    
kube-controller-manager-1756656909-wdmkg   1/1       Running       0          12d       10.5.62.4 
kube-controller-manager-889084721-drbkh    0/1       Pending       0          9s        <none>
kube-controller-manager-889084721-sn6xg    0/1       Pending       0          9s        <none>
```

Which is what I expected. The rollout status at the same time though showed: 
```
kb rollout status deploy/kube-controller-manager
Waiting for rollout to finish: 2 out of 3 new replicas have been updated...
```

2 out of the 3 replicas had not been updated successfully. They were still in a pending state as you can see above. 

This continued one, until rollout status said the rolling out was done

`deployment "kube-controller-manager" successfully rolled out`

However, the actual status of the rollout was:

```
kb get po -l k8s-app=kube-controller-manager -o wide
NAME                                      READY     STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE       IP         
kube-controller-manager-889084721-8ppdm   1/1       Running   0          1m        10.5.57.4   
kube-controller-manager-889084721-drbkh   0/1       Pending   0          1m        <none>
kube-controller-manager-889084721-sn6xg   1/1       Running   0          1m        10.5.14.6   
```

**What you expected to happen**:

I expect kubectl to understand that pending does not mean it was successfully applied. That last pending pod could have failed; however, automated deployment scripts that depend on rollout status would have thought everything was OK. 

**How to reproduce it** (as minimally and precisely as possible):

Apply an update to a pod that uses anti-affinity to limit the number of pods per node and limit the number of nodes to the same as replicas.
